did.unittitle: Rensis Likert papers
did.abstract: Social scientist, director of the Institute for Social Research of the University of Michigan. Papers include project files, survey research data and reports, and printed material, largely from his work with the Division of Program Surveys, Bureau of Agricultural Economics and the office of War Information during World War II; Office Of Strategic Bombing Survey, I.S.R. project files; and transcript of oral interview, 1970.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection (Donor No. 5109) was first accessioned in 1975. Periodic additions have been received since then. 5109

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to the regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Rensis Likert Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Rensis Likert was born August 5, 1903 in Cheyenne, Wyoming. He received his B.A. in chemical engineering from the University of Michigan in 1926, and his Ph.D. in social psychology from Columbia University in 1932. At Columbia, Likert worked under Gardner Murphy and first did work in measuring attitudes. After a period as an instructor of psychology and later assistant professor at New York University, Likert became director of research for the Life Insurance Agency Management Association of Hartford, Connecticut, working in this capacity from December 1935 to September 1939.

In September 1939, following a reorganization of the U.S. Department of Agriculture, Likert was selected to administer the Division of Program Surveys in the Bureau of Agricultural Economics (BAE), serving from 1939 to October 1946. His overall responsibility was the development of more scientific opinion surveys, and in this capacity, he and his staff conducted interviews which were at first concerned with problems of agricultural production and management, but which broadened out with World War II into studies of citizen morale and problems of the home front. While with BAE, Likert also conducted specialized surveys for the Office of War Information (OWI), the U.S. Department of Treasury, and the Federal Reserve Board. He also served during the latter stages of World War II as director of the Morale Division of the U.S. Strategic Bombing Survey, serving from November 1944 to June 1946.

With the conclusion of the war and a decline in government support, Likert began looking for a university setting where he and his staff could continue to do their research and conduct surveys on theoretical and social problems. The University of Michigan was selected, and on July 1, 1946, the Survey Research Center was established. In 1948 the Research Center for Group Dynamics left M.I.T. to join the University of Michigan. The combined organization became known as the Institute for Social Research (ISR). Likert served as director of the Survey Research Center from its founding in 1946 until he assumed the directorship of the new Institute for Social Research. He remained as director of ISR until his retirement in 1970.

In 1971, Likert formed a private consulting firm, Rensis Likert Associates, Inc. (RLA). The firm located its headquarters in Ann Arbor and established regional offices across the nation. RLA studied management styles and management systems in conjunction with survey research. The success of the firm stemmed from its utilization of Likert's Systems 1-4, which recognized and identified patterns of management, aiding businesses in achieving the most beneficial system of management.

list.head: Summary Contents List
list.item: Biographical Material, including transcripts of oral interviews [Box 1]

Bureau of Agricultural Economics [Boxes 1-8, 23-24] Bureau History and Related Materials [Box 1] Reports and Memoranda, 1939-1949 [Boxes 1-5; 23; 24] Background Files [Boxes 5-8, 23] Administrative Files [Box 23] Survey Research [Box 23] Methodology [Box 23] Division of Program Surveys [Box 23-24]

Office of War Information [Boxes 9-11] Reports and Memoranda [Boxes 9-10, 11] Survey of Intelligence Materials [Box 10] Intelligence Reports [Box 10] Miscellaneous files [Box 11] Administrative files [Box 11]
U.S. Strategic Bombing Survey [Boxes 11-13] Department Reports [Box 11-12] Miscellaneous Reports and Documents [Box 12-13] Administrative [Box 13]

Institute for Social Research/Survey Research Center [Boxes 13-20] Background [Box 13] Project files [Box 13-17] Building Fund-Raising Campaign [Box 18] Correspondence [Boxes 18-19] Administrative and miscellaneous files [Boxes 19-20]
Early Career [Boxes 21] Psychological Corporation [Box 21] Newell-Emmett Company [Box 21] Life Insurance Sales Research Bureau [Box 21]

scopecontent.p: The Rensis Likert Papers document his work as one of the pioneers of survey research, first with the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, then with the Office of War Information, Office of Strategic Bombing Surveys and finally at the University of Michigan's Survey Research Center and Institute for Social Research. The papers include biographical information on Likert; transcripts of oral history interviews with Likert; reports, background information, correspondence relating to various survey projects.

The Likert papers were received and initially processed in four accessions in 1975, 1982,1990 and 1995. Material in later accessions sometimes continued or complemented records series in prior accessions. The papers are boxed in an order that reflects the dates the accessions individual accessions were received. In this finding aid the disparate parts of series received in multiple accessions have been together to reflect the intellectual arrangement of the collection. As a result, the box-folder sequence in he contents listing are not always consecutive.

The materials in the 1975 accession (boxes 1-20) of the Rensis Likert Papers cover the period of 1939 to 1953 and largely concern Likert's work at the Bureau of Agricultural Economics and the Office of War Information during World War II and his subsequent work in the early development of the Survey Research Center.

In 1982 the family of Rensis Likert donated an additional three feet (boxes 21-23) of materials. Notable items in this accession concern Likert's work as assistant secretary and treasurer of the Psychological Corporation (1934-1935); consultant to the Newell-Emmett Company (1935); survey researcher with the Morale Division of the United States Strategic Bombing Survey unit (ca. 1944-1946); and activities with other professional organizations (ca. 1938-1949)

The third accession of the Likert papers (box 24-29) came from the library of the Institute of Social Research of the University of Michigan. The files pertain to all phases of Likert's professional career, and thus the researcher should use these papers in conjunction with the materials in the previous accessions. The final accession (box 29) was received form several sources.

did.unittitle: Biographical material

scopecontent.p: Biographical includes clippings and transcripts of oral interviews conducted with Rensis Likert.

did.unittitle: Transcripts of oral interviews
Biographical material
Bureau of Agricultural Economics

scopecontent.p: The series Bureau of Agricultural Economics contains reports and memoranda created by the BAE. Both rural and urban topics are covered in the pre-war reports and memoranda. Topics during the war years include studies on rationing, production, labor, and war loan drives. The reports are arranged chronologically and contain occasional background files relating to a specific report or study.

Office of War Information

scopecontent.p: The series Office of War Information (formerly Office of Facts and Figures) contains copies of the official newsletter Current Surveys, as well as reports and memoranda specifically related to war-time topics. The reports are primarily studies of public perception and reaction to home front policies. Among the topics covered are attitudes toward various ethnic and racial groups, morale, and preliminary perceptions of the post-war world. The materials are arranged chronologically and include correspondence, notes, and related information.

United States Strategic Bombing Survey, US War Dept., Morale Division

scopecontent.p: The U.S. Strategic Bombing Survey series consists of final reports and extensive background information in the form of field notes, completed questionnaires, and transcripts of interviews with detailed information on conditions in Germany and Japan during and immediately after World War II. Some of the work documented in this series was conducted during the occupation of Japan and relates to the aftermath of the dropping of the atom bombs.

Institute for Social Research / Survey Research Center

scopecontent.p: The Survey Research Center/Institute for Social Research series contains materials from the early project files of the Survey Research Center. The project files consist of attitude surveys and studies. The files contain both background material and final reports. This series also contains notebooks of project materials, building fund raising files, and correspondence files. Materials in this series are largely arranged chronologically with the exception of project reports which are arranged in their original sequential numbering system.

Early Career

scopecontent.p: The Early Career series documents Likert's work as a researcher director of research in the 1930s. The first two small series - Psychological Corporation and Newell-Emmett Company - document specific studies, one of which concerns the public's radio listening habits and gasoline purchasing habits. The subseries, Life Insurance Sales Research Bureau, documents Likert's entry into the survey research field. This portion of the collection includes lecture notes and student papers written for Likert while at Columbia University. It also includes early opinion survey questionnaires and correspondence produced while with the Life Insurance Sales Research Bureau.

scopecontent.p: The series related to Likert's Association and Committee activities (ca. 1938-1949) is incomplete, and documents only a small percentage of Likert's professional involvements, notably correspondence and bulletins from the American Association for Applied Psychology, 1938-1945; fragmentary background for a proposal of the American Psychological Association, Society for the Psychological Study of Social Issues, 1947; notes for a 1945 discussion before the British Social Psychologists; correspondence, charts, and reports associated with the Committee for National Morale, ca. 1940-1941; summary records of the 1949 meeting held in Paris of the Committee of Scientific Experts on International Research Laboratories; and conference minutes (1944) and miscellaneous papers (ca. 1942-1944) of the Committee on Food Habits.

Rensis Likert and Associates

scopecontent.p: The Rensis Likert Associates series is primarily correspondence generated during the 1970s. This series consists of both incoming and outgoing correspondence which illuminate the nature of his consulting. Both individuals and corporations are represented in the correspondence. Correspondence retains the original alphabetical arrangement as received by the library.

Published Works

scopecontent.p: The series, Published Works, consists of articles and reprints of Likert's writings. The series spans 1934 to 1979, covering both his earliest and latest work. The series is arranged chronologically and includes a bibliography of his writings. Six booklets on morale produced for the Life Insurance Sales Research Bureau in 1940 are included here. They were produced by Likert, but contain no statement of authorship.

scopecontent.p: Photographs include pictures taken in Japan relating to study of the effects of bombing on Japanese morale undertaken for the United States Strategic and photos from an agricultural survey exhibit.
